#â€‹577 â€” November 5, 2025

Read the WebÂ Version

Go Weekly

"I'm Independently Verifying Go's Reproducible Builds" â€” Since Go 1.21, every release of the Go toolchain can be rebuilt from source and result in an identical byte-for-byte output, regardless of environment. Itâ€™s a big security win that enables automatic build verification using checksums, but having an independent third party verify things too makes the system even moreÂ robust.

Andrew Ayer

Agentic Postgres: AI-Ready Postgres for Go developers â€” Tiger Dataâ€™s Agentic Postgres turns vanilla Postgres into an AI-native database. Fork DBs, give agents memory, and query via REST or CLI. Perfect for Go backends building with Claude, Cursor, or custom agents. Try it freeâ€”no cardÂ needed.

Tiger Data sponsor

Dependency Management in Database Design â€” A case study in modular architecture and dependency management in Go projects, something many projects struggle with once they grow beyond a few packages. Hereâ€™s how the Dolt database system (made up of 762k lines of Go code) handlesÂ it.

Nick Tobey (DoltHub)

ğŸ¤–Â Claude Code Can Debug Low-Level Cryptography â€” You might know Filippo for his tireless work on cryptography in Go and heâ€™s now created an implementation of ML-DSA, a post-quantum signature algorithm. He got stuck on a bug and was very impressed when Claude Code managed to discover "a fairly complex low-levelÂ bug."

Filippo Valsorda

Revisiting Interface Segregation in Go â€” Also known as the â€œIâ€ in the â€œSOLIDâ€ principles.

Redowan Delowar

ğŸ“„ How We Saved 70% CPU and 60% Memory in Refineryâ€™s Go Code â€“ Sometimes itâ€™s about what you shouldnâ€™t beÂ doing.. Ian Wilkes

ğŸ“„ Rendering an Animated Plasma Effect with Ebiten Slicker

ğŸ“„ switch Statements in Go Angela Xie

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

Chans: Building Blocks for Idiomatic Go Pipelines â€” Anton shows off his chans package which provides generic channel operations (filter, map, partition, take while, etc.) for putting together concurrentÂ pipelines.

Anton Zhiyanov

Make Remote Pair Programming Fun Again â€” 92% of surveyed Tuple users say that using Tuple makes them happier at work. Find outÂ why.

Tuple sponsor

Livecore: A Low-Pause Core File Dumper for Linux Processes â€” Former Go language team member Brad Fitzpatrick decided to try â€œvibe codingâ€ for the first time ever and produced this tool for producing core files from running processes on Linux using goref.

Brad Fitzpatrick

go-sqlite3: Go Bindings to SQLite Using Wazero â€” One of a growing number of ways to use SQLite from Go. This one is cgo-free and provides a database/sql compatible way to work with a WebAssembly build of SQLite run through wazero.

Nuno Cruces

docxgo: A Library for Manipulating Microsoft Word Documents â€” Check out the code samples for an idea of the basics. An evolution of the Docx library.

Misael Monterroca et al.

ğŸ–¼ï¸Â progjpeg: image/jpeg But With Progressive Encoding Support â€” Itâ€™s Goâ€™s image/jpeg package but with support for progressive encoding (where an image is shown in increasing resolution as itâ€™s loaded in). A niche feature, but one whose issue was â€˜frozenâ€™ on the official GoÂ repo.

David Le Corfec

Concord: A Resilient Chord Implementation in Go â€” Chord is a peer-to-peer distributed hash tableÂ mechanism.

Olle LÃ¶gdahl

  • ğŸ¤– Crush 0.15 â€“ Charm's Go-powered AI coding agent. Now with an 'agentic fetch' feature for working with remoteÂ content.

  • Vitess 23.0 â€“ Popular horizontal scaling system forÂ MySQL.

  • deque 1.2 â€“ Fast ring-buffer deque (double-ended queue).

  • Lazygit 0.56 â€“ Simple terminal UI for git commands.

  • Gitea 1.25 â€“ Popular self-hosted Git platform.

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

Software Engineer - Join our "kick ass" team! Our software team operates from 17 countries and we're looking for more exceptional engineers to join ourÂ team.

ğŸ˜ Postgres user? Be sure to check out our sister newsletter, Postgres Weekly.

ğŸ“¢Â  Elsewhere in the ecosystem

Some other interesting stories in the broader landscape:

  • ğŸ§‹ The first release candidate of Bubble Tea 2.0 is here, and big changes are on the way for the popular TUI framework's import URL, as well as other features mentioned in earlier beta release notes, if you'd like to get ahead of the eventualÂ release.

  • A look into how JavaScript source maps work under the hood and how all the pieces fit together to make them useful.

  • ğŸ“Š GitHub published its annual Octoverse data report and Go was the tenth most popular language on the platform in 2025.

  • Git 2.0 was released over ten years ago, but Git 3.0 is on the way in 2026 and you can learn a little about what the upgrade willÂ entail.

  • pgfeaturediff is a site for quickly comparing features between different versions ofÂ PostgreSQL.

item.title: ã€A tour of Go's newest garbage collectorã€‘Go æœ€æ–°çš„åƒåœ¾æ”¶é›†å™¨ä¹‹æ—…
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹576 â€” October 29, 2025

Read the WebÂ Version

Go Weekly

Go's Green Tea Garbage Collector â€” Go 1.25 introduced a new, experimental garbage collector called â€˜Green Teaâ€™. Though experimental, itâ€™s already in production at Google and theyâ€™ve seen big efficiency gains (though others have seen little benefit). This post goes into depth about how it operates and compares to Goâ€™s defaultÂ GC.

Michael Knyszek and Austin Clements

ğŸ’¬ There's a more extensive thread of people's Green Tea benchmarks on GitHub.

Build Enterprise Features Faster with WorkOS â€” Enterprise customers expect SSO, SCIM, and RBAC that meet strict compliance standards. WorkOS gives developers clean APIs, built-in SOC 2 and GDPR support, and a hosted Admin Portal to help ship enterprise features without slowing downÂ development.

WorkOS sponsor

Go's Release Cycle and Process as Go 1.26 Progresses â€” Go 1.26â€™s â€œdevelopment freezeâ€ is scheduled for November 26, meaning that any new features going into Go 1.26 have to be committed by then (bug fixes and doc updates continue, however). This page, maintained by the Go team, explains how the process between then and Go 1.26â€™s eventual release in 2026 willÂ go.

Go Wiki

IN BRIEF:

  • Users of the Go subreddit (/r/golang) got to discussing and sharing their favorite Go related blog posts of all time.

  • Ian Lance Taylor reflects on using JSON schemas in Go and the work done at Google to make this a reality, both in google/jsonschema-go and Ian's own ianlancetaylor/jsonschema.

vite-plugin-use-golang: Write Go in JavaScript Files? â€” An interesting experiment! Itâ€™s a plugin for the Vite frontend build tool that looks for a "use golang" directive in â€˜JavaScriptâ€™ files and compiles the Go code found there to WebAssembly for use on the front-end. â€œItâ€™s absurd, but itâ€™sÂ real.â€

Yar Kravtsov

Timezones as Types: Making Time Safer to Use in Go? â€” The creator of go-meridian shows off how the library can bring types to timezones â€œmaking wrong timezone handling impossible toÂ compile.â€

Matthew Halpern

ğŸ“„ The Concurrency Conundrum: A Story of Curiosity and Code â€“ The tale of tackling a typical lockingÂ problem. Wawandco

ğŸ“„ From 19 Hours to Under a Second: Building a Blazing-Fast TCP Scanner in Go Michael Freeman

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

ğŸ¤–Â Crush: Charm's Go-Powered AI Coding Agent â€” A few months ago we noticed the first commits to this repo, but now Charm (best known for Bubble Tea) has built a fleshed out, featureful alternative to tools like Claude Code or OpenAIâ€™s Codex thatâ€™s well worth checkingÂ out, especially as it supports any OpenAI-compatible LLMÂ API.

Charm

Lessons Learned from a Decade of Managing K8s: The DefinitiveÂ Guide â€” Discover what 10 years of Kubernetes ops taught us about building, securing, and scaling platforms withÂ confidence.

Fairwinds sponsor

Fyne: A GUI App Framework for Desktop, Mobile and Web â€” A neat way to build GUI and mobile apps with Go and one of few options for creating native cross-platform apps without having to package a full browser engine. Itâ€™s had some significant updates recently in areas like i18n, canvas drawing, and styling. GitHubÂ repo.

Fyne Team

ğŸ¤–Â Fantasy: Build Flexible AI Agents with Go â€” Itâ€™s Charm again! Fantasy is one of the key building blocks behind Crush (mentioned above) but can be used directly to create tool-enabled agents inÂ Go.

Charm

SFTPGo 2.7: A Full Featured File Transfer Solution â€” A highly configurable, Go-powered SFTP, HTTP/S, FTP/S and WebDAV server that can interoperate with cloud-based storage backends. v2.7 adds support for Post-Quantum Traditional Hybrid Key Exchange and drops rsync and Git hosting support. GitHub repo. AGPL 3.0Â licensed.

Drakkan

  • go-redis 9.16 â€“ Redis clientÂ library. Now with support for Redis maintenance notifications and traceÂ filtering.

  • Grype 0.102 â€“ Vulnerability scanner for container images andÂ filesystems.

  • Vacuum 0.19.4 â€“ OpenAPI / Swagger linter and quality analysisÂ tool.

  • Vale 3.13 â€“ CLI tool for code-like linting of prose/naturalÂ language.

item.description:
ã€

#â€‹575 â€” October 22, 2025

Read the WebÂ Version

Go Weekly

The Draft Go 1.26 Release Notes â€” Itâ€™s still early days for the under-development Go 1.26, due to land in February 2026, but thereâ€™s already a draft set of release notes covering enhancements most likely committed to the release so far, including newâ€™s support forÂ expressions.

The Go Team

The â€œ10xâ€ Commandments of Highly EffectiveÂ Go â€” John comes down from the mountain with ten Go commandments. The conceit may be cute, but these are essentially ten broad guidelines for Go developers, coupled with examples of adopting them inÂ GoLand.

John Arundel

Automate GitHub Actions Runner Updates with Claude â€” Forget about managing GitHub Actions runners and get back to writing code. Learn how Depot uses Claude to automatically handle all those pesky updates and how you can get faster, more stable CI/CD without theÂ headache.

Depot sponsor

IN BRIEF:

  • ğŸ“Š JetBrains (creator of GoLand) has released the results of its latest 'State of Developer Ecosystem Report' with Go at #4 in its 'Language Promise Index' and #1 in 'languages developers want to adopt next.'

  • The popular Go-powered Caddy HTTPS server project is now 11 years old and Matt Holt shares some updates on next steps for the project's long-term maintenance.

  • Writing Better Go: Lessons from 10 Code Reviews is a fantastic set of slides from a recent talk by Konrad Reiche at GoLab 2025.

The Speed of Random Number Generators â€” There are several obvious options for generating random numbers in Go â€“ Daniel quickly compares their performance (spoiler: math/rand/v2 using PCG is theÂ winner).

Daniel Lemire

The 'Compare IP Subnets' Proposal â€” As part of his Accepted! series explaining upcoming changes to Go, Anton explains how Go 1.26 will make comparing IP subnets (e.g. 10.0.0.0/8) easier.

Anton Zhiyanov

ğŸ“„ Parsing Financial News for Automated Trading Decisions â€“ But always remember, folks: â€œtime in the market beats timing the marketâ€ ;-) Paolo Galeone

ğŸ“„ JWT Authentication in Go with Gin â€“ With the end goal to work with Vonage in this case, but the principles can be usedÂ elsewhere. Benjamin Aronov (Vonage)

ğŸ“„ Durable Background Execution with Go and SQLite Dima Kotik

ğŸ“„ Subtest Grouping in Go Redowan Delowar

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

gotests: Automatically Generate Test Boilerplate From Code â€” Automatically creates table-driven tests from your source code by analyzing function and method signatures. This weekâ€™s v1.8.0 release adds complete support for generics, meaning gotests can generate tests for generic functions and methods on genericÂ types.

Charles Weill et al.

What Shopify, Figma, and Stripe Use for Pair Programming â€” Tuple is the most effective way to unblock PRs, make technical decisions, and polish or reviewÂ code.

Tuple sponsor

urfave/cli 3.1: A Declarative Way to Build Go CLI Apps â€” The manual outlines all of the key features, but think shell auto-completion, option parsing, help text, etc.

Jeremy Saenz and Contributors

go-torch: Torch-Like Deep Learning Framework in Go â€” Open-source deep learning framework built from the ground up in pureÂ Go.

Abinesh Mathivanan

go-nvtrust: NVIDIA GPU and NVSwitch Confidential Computing Attestation â€” This is niche! Itâ€™s a Go version of Nvidiaâ€™s nvTrust to manage â€˜Confidential Computingâ€™ attestation evidence from NVIDIAÂ GPUs.

Confident Security

  • ğŸ“ˆ go-echarts 2.6.5 â€“ Charting and data visualization library that uses ApacheÂ ECharts. You can see examples in theÂ docs.

  • ğŸ’¬ go-xmpp v0.2.18 â€“ XMPP client library. There's even a basic GUI chat app example in just 113 lines ofÂ code.

  • Hugo 0.152.0 â€“ The popular static site generator has changed its YAML-parsing library, so take care if you use the terms 'yes', 'no', 'on', 'off' or variants of those in your YAMLÂ files.

  • Lefthook 2.0 â€“ Fast and powerful Git hooks manager.

  • ğŸ¤– Gobot 2.6 â€“ Robotics / drones / IoTÂ framework.

ğŸ And one for fun..

superfile: Go-Powered Terminal-Based FileÂ Manager â€” A modern, well-styled (and theme-able) terminal based file manager app built atop Bubble Tea. GitHubÂ repo.

Yorukot

item.title: ã€Is channel-based iteration slow?ã€‘åŸºäºé€šé“çš„è¿­ä»£é€Ÿåº¦æ…¢å—ï¼Ÿ
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹574 â€” October 15, 2025

Read the WebÂ Version

Go Weekly

15 Go Subtleties You May Not Already Know â€” A well written roundup of lesser-known Go features or idiosyncrasies thatâ€™s worth a skim even if only a few jump out at you. Or if you already know about them all, you can feel a warm glow for the rest of the day ğŸ˜ Topics include time.After, nil interfaces, and jsonâ€™s - tag.

Harrison Cramer

Get Oâ€™Reilly Book Data Engineering Design Patterns, Courtesy of Buf â€” Discover proven design patterns for building reliable, scalable data systems. This free Oâ€™Reilly ebook, courtesy of Buf, focuses on several important aspects of data engineering, including data ingestion, data quality, idempotency, andÂ more.

Buf sponsor

How Slow is Channel-Based Iteration? â€” The makers of the Go-powered Dolt database run an example involving iteration using two channel-based approaches, as well as iter.Pull. Conclusion? â€œThe haters are right: using channels for iteration isÂ slow.â€

Zach Musgrave

IN BRIEF:

  • Go 1.25.3 and 1.24.9 have been released. They're minor point releases which address a problem caused by an earlier security patch being overly restrictive when parsing X.509Â certificates.
